areas.name: Bukchon
areas.summary: Quiet hanok lanes with polished galleries and tea spots.
areas.hook: If you start Seoul with one soft morning, make it this one.
areas.friend_note: I still like Bukchon most before 10am. By noon, the same lane can feel like a photo queue.
areas.best_time: 08:30-11:00 for soft light and fewer groups
areas.how_to_get: Anguk Station (Line 3), Exit 2, then 10-minute uphill walk
areas.must_do: Walk Gahoe-dong alley loop and stop at a hanok tea house
areas.hidden_tip: Use side streets near Bukchon-ro 11-gil for quieter views
areas.do_not: Avoid loud calls and door-front photos in residential lanes
areas.photo_spot: Bukchon Observatory side lane at around 09:00
areas.food_pairing: Doenjang jjigae lunch in Insadong after the walk
areas.rain_option: Swap to nearby craft museums and a longer tea break
areas.night_option: Keep night elsewhere; Bukchon is best daytime
areas.one_line_route: Anguk Exit 2 -> hanok lanes -> tea house -> Samcheong walk

areas.name: Seongsu
areas.summary: Creative warehouse district with fashion pop-ups and coffee labs.
areas.hook: Seongsu is where your camera roll fills up fast.
areas.friend_note: Seongsu feels fun but can get exhausting fast. I cap it at two key spots and one solid meal.
areas.how_to_get: Seongsu Station (Line 2), Exit 3, walk toward Yeonmujang-gil
areas.must_do: Pair one flagship store visit with a specialty cafe
areas.hidden_tip: Weekdays before noon are much easier for popular lines
areas.do_not: Do not plan too many stops, queues can eat your schedule
areas.budget: Mid to high depending on shopping
areas.food_pairing: Add one modern Korean dinner near Ttukseom
areas.rain_option: Use pop-up stores and indoor galleries as the core
areas.night_option: Shift to Seoul Forest side bars after 20:00
areas.one_line_route: Seongsu Exit 3 -> pop-up -> coffee lab -> Seoul Forest

areas.name: Hongdae
areas.summary: Youthful street energy, live busking, and late-night food options.
areas.hook: This is your loud, fun, low-commitment night.
areas.friend_note: Hongdae is chaos in a good way. I usually warm up in Yeonnam first, then jump into the main blocks.
areas.best_time: 18:00-23:30 for music and night street mood
areas.must_do: Watch buskers near main square then move to side alley bars
areas.hidden_tip: Use Yeonnam side streets for slower pace between peak blocks
areas.do_not: Skip main strip restaurants at 19:00-20:30 unless you pre-book
areas.photo_spot: Street murals in Yeonnam before full dark
areas.food_pairing: Fried chicken + draft beer combo near Sangsu
areas.rain_option: Arcades, indoor bars, and basement live clubs
areas.night_option: Best after 21:00 if you like busking crowds
areas.one_line_route: Yeonnam warm-up -> busking square -> dinner -> late bar

areas.name: Euljiro
areas.summary: Old-printing alley charm mixed with hip bars and rooftops.
areas.hook: Euljiro feels like your cool local friend showed you a secret floor.
areas.friend_note: Euljiro is the place where you trust floor numbers, not first impressions from street level.
areas.must_do: Start with roast pork alley then rooftop or speakeasy
areas.hidden_tip: Google Maps pin names can differ from signboards here
areas.do_not: Do not expect polished interiors everywhere
areas.crowd: High on Friday and Saturday nights
areas.photo_spot: Neon-lit alley corners near Sewoon Plaza
areas.rain_option: Lean into indoor bars connected by short walks
areas.one_line_route: Euljiro 3-ga -> pork alley -> craft bar -> rooftop

areas.name: Mangwon
areas.summary: Neighborhood market life with relaxed local cafes and river access.
areas.hook: Mangwon is the easiest area to feel like you are not rushing.
areas.friend_note: Mangwon feels like a real weekend Seoul pace: snack, walk, sit, then snack again.
areas.must_do: Mangwon Market snack crawl then Hangang riverside walk
areas.hidden_tip: Carry small cash for older market stalls
areas.do_not: Do not stack too many far-away reservations on the same day
areas.photo_spot: Mangwon Market entrance + Han River sunset edge
areas.food_pairing: Kimbap, croquette, and bingsu split with friends
areas.rain_option: Focus on market aisles and cafe hopping
areas.night_option: Keep it short and move to Hapjeong for dinner
areas.one_line_route: Mangwon market -> cafe -> riverside -> Hapjeong dinner

themes.title: Cafe Day
themes.summary: A full day of Seoul cafe culture with pace, not pressure.
themes.hook: No speedrun, just really good coffee and streets you want to stay in.
themes.friend_note: Pick one signature drink per stop instead of full meals. You will enjoy the day longer.
themes.ideal_for: Solo travelers and couples who enjoy long conversations
themes.flow: Morning in Bukchon, afternoon in Seongsu, evening in Hannam
themes.highlight: Three distinct cafe moods in one day without rushing
themes.food_break: Light pasta or sandwich between second and third cafe
themes.rain_swap: Swap Bukchon walk with indoor bookstore cafe
themes.creator_note: Best when it feels like a voice memo from a friend, not a polished ad cut.

themes.title: Traditional
themes.summary: Classic Seoul texture through palaces, hanok lanes, and tea.
themes.hook: This is the route people thank themselves for not skipping.
themes.friend_note: Start with palace first. Once crowd grows, move to lanes and tea.
themes.ideal_for: First-time visitors wanting depth in one compact route
themes.flow: Gyeongbokgung, Bukchon walk, Insadong tea and crafts
themes.highlight: Strong cultural context without feeling tourist-heavy
themes.creator_note: This route works because the texture changes every hour: palace stone, hanok wood, tea steam.

themes.title: Night Seoul
themes.summary: An after-dark route with skyline, food, and creative streets.
themes.hook: Seoul after sunset has layers. This route lets you feel all three.
themes.friend_note: Keep one hour buffer between dinner and late spot. Traffic and queues happen.
themes.flow: Sunset at Namsan area, dinner in Euljiro, late walk in Hongdae
themes.highlight: Balanced energy from scenic to social
themes.food_break: Korean BBQ in Euljiro before bar move
themes.creator_note: The emotional peak is usually right after dinner when neon lights kick in.

themes.title: Rainy Seoul
themes.summary: A weather-proof day with covered markets, museum breaks, and cozy cafes.
themes.hook: Rain day does not kill Seoul. It actually gives you better mood shots.
themes.friend_note: Use short taxi hops between indoor clusters and keep shoes water-safe.
themes.ideal_for: Travelers visiting in monsoon season or shoulder weather
themes.flow: Museum morning, covered market lunch, cafe-heavy afternoon
themes.highlight: Low stress and high comfort without wasting a day
themes.food_break: Hot noodle soup or jeon on rainy noon
themes.creator_note: Rainy day footage looks best when you include reflections and crowded indoor heat.

themes.title: Morning Seoul
themes.summary: An early-day itinerary for travelers who want calm streets and cleaner photos.
themes.hook: If you wake up early, Seoul gives you private-looking moments.
themes.friend_note: Finish your key shots before 10:30, then brunch while crowds build.
themes.ideal_for: Photographers and travelers adjusting to jet lag
themes.flow: Sunrise view, market breakfast, quiet lane walk
themes.highlight: Low crowd density and efficient movement
themes.food_break: Early kalguksu or toast and coffee
themes.rain_swap: Switch sunrise view to covered observatory
themes.creator_note: Morning Seoul feels cleaner and quieter; footsteps and ambient sound carry the story.

tips.title: Payment
tips.summary: Cards are widely accepted, but not every global card works equally.
tips.hook: Seoul is card-friendly, but backup is still the smart move.
tips.friend_note: I always carry two cards and enough cash for one meal + one taxi.
tips.what_to_know: Visa and Mastercard usually work in most chains and larger shops.
tips.why_it_matters: Small places and older kiosks may reject foreign cards without warning.
tips.avoid_this: Do not rely on one card for your full trip.
tips.quick_fix: Carry one backup card and a small amount of cash.
tips.real_scene: At some Gwangjang stalls, cards work one day and fail the next depending on terminal status.
tips.local_move: Top-up transit and keep a 10,000 KRW emergency note.
tips.line_to_use: Card an dwaeyo? Hyeongeum do dwaeyo?

tips.title: Transport
tips.summary: Subway + bus is the easiest way to move fast across neighborhoods.
tips.hook: One transit card solves 80 percent of city movement.
tips.friend_note: Plan your big cross-city move before dinner peak, not during it.
tips.what_to_know: Buy a transit card once and recharge at convenience stores.
tips.why_it_matters: Transfers are cheaper and smoother with one tap-based card.
tips.avoid_this: Avoid rush hour with luggage when possible.
tips.quick_fix: Travel major moves before 17:30 or after 19:30.
tips.real_scene: Line 2 around Gangnam and Hongdae can feel packed enough to skip one train during peak.
tips.local_move: Use subway for long moves and short taxi for final uphill blocks.

tips.title: Etiquette
tips.summary: Simple social cues keep interactions warm and respectful.
tips.hook: Small manners make service warmer almost instantly.
tips.friend_note: You do not need perfect Korean, just calm tone and spatial awareness.
tips.what_to_know: Keep voice low on public transport and queues orderly.
tips.why_it_matters: Small behavior signals strongly affect service tone.
tips.avoid_this: Avoid blocking narrow alleys for photos.
tips.quick_fix: Step aside first, then take your shot.
tips.real_scene: In tight cafe aisles in Seongsu, staff will quickly ask people to move if photo lines block flow.
tips.local_move: Quick bow + gamsahamnida after help goes a long way.

tips.title: Airport to City
tips.summary: AREX + short taxi is often the smoothest first-day combo.
tips.hook: Do not overthink your first transfer. Keep it simple and low-friction.
tips.friend_note: If you land tired, spend a little more for the final 10-minute taxi.
tips.what_to_know: Airport Railroad is predictable and avoids highway traffic variables.
tips.why_it_matters: You protect energy for day one instead of burning it on logistics.
tips.avoid_this: Avoid multi-transfer subway routes with heavy luggage.
tips.quick_fix: Take AREX to a major hub then taxi to hotel.
tips.real_scene: Late evening arrival with two bags feels much easier this way.
tips.local_move: Prepare hotel name in Korean on your phone before taxi.

tips.title: SIM and Wi-Fi
tips.summary: Reliable data makes every map, booking, and translation easier.
tips.hook: Good connection is not optional in Seoul travel, it is core infrastructure.
tips.friend_note: Set this up before leaving the airport and your first day gets much easier.
tips.what_to_know: eSIM is fastest if your phone supports it; pocket Wi-Fi is best for groups.
tips.why_it_matters: Map apps and reservation links are used constantly in Seoul.
tips.avoid_this: Do not wait until your battery and patience are low.
tips.quick_fix: Activate eSIM at airport and test map route before departure.
tips.real_scene: No data in a transfer station can derail dinner reservations quickly.
tips.local_move: Save one offline map area as backup.

tips.title: Cafe Ordering
tips.summary: Many popular cafes use kiosk ordering and quick pick-up flow.
tips.hook: Cafe lines move fast here if you know the pattern.
tips.friend_note: Decide your menu before you reach the kiosk. It keeps everyone happy.
tips.what_to_know: Takeout and dine-in can be separate options on kiosks.
tips.why_it_matters: Wrong option can cause seating confusion and delays.
tips.avoid_this: Avoid standing at pick-up counter while deciding.
tips.quick_fix: Check menu board, order once, then wait by number call.
tips.real_scene: Peak-hour Seongsu cafes can clear 20+ orders quickly.
tips.local_move: If unsure, show screen and politely ask staff for confirmation.

korea101.title: Subway & Bus Basics
korea101.summary: How locals move fast in Seoul without burning energy.
korea101.hook: One transit card can save your whole trip pace.
korea101.friend_note: Mix subway for long moves and short taxi hops for the final 10 minutes.
korea101.comic_scene: A traveler runs to the wrong platform, then a local points to line color + direction and everything clicks.
korea101.core_idea: Seoul transit is easy once you track line color, terminal station, and transfer signs.
korea101.fun_fact: Many transfer stations are like underground mini-cities with shops and long walking paths.
korea101.real_life_tip: Avoid rush peaks around 8:00-9:00 and 18:00-19:30 for easier rides.
korea101.line_to_use: Does this train go to Hongdae?

korea101.title: Payment & Cash Reality
korea101.summary: Cards work almost everywhere, but backup still matters.
korea101.friend_note: Carry two cards and small cash to avoid awkward dead-ends.
korea101.comic_scene: Card works at a flagship cafe, fails at a tiny market stall two hours later.
korea101.core_idea: Use card by default, but expect occasional terminal mismatch in smaller shops.
korea101.fun_fact: Convenience stores often become emergency hubs for top-up, snacks, and backup cash handling.
korea101.real_life_tip: Keep 10,000-30,000 KRW cash for markets, old kiosks, or late-night spots.
korea101.line_to_use: Card is not working. Can I pay cash?

korea101.title: Restaurant Culture 101
korea101.summary: From side dishes to table bells, the flow can feel different for newcomers.
korea101.hook: Knowing the rhythm makes meals smoother than speaking perfect Korean.
korea101.friend_note: If staff seem fast, that is normal service tempo, not rudeness.
korea101.comic_scene: A visitor waits quietly while locals press the call bell and order in 20 seconds.
korea101.core_idea: Korean dining often rewards quick decisions and direct requests.
korea101.fun_fact: At many places, side dishes are refillable and water is self-serve.
korea101.real_life_tip: Decide menu before sitting in busy areas to reduce queue stress.
korea101.line_to_use: Can we get one more side dish, please?

korea101.title: Cafe Rules & Kiosk Flow
korea101.summary: Seat, order, pickup: the order sequence matters in popular cafes.
korea101.hook: The line looks scary, but the system is usually efficient.
korea101.friend_note: Pick one signature menu fast, then move to pickup flow.
korea101.comic_scene: Someone freezes at the kiosk while the queue behind moves like a speedrun.
korea101.core_idea: Korean cafes optimize speed with clear self-service zones and pickup counters.
korea101.fun_fact: Some cafes enforce one drink per person during busy hours.
korea101.real_life_tip: Check if it is dine-in or takeaway before payment to avoid reorder.

korea101.title: Convenience Store Is a Life Hub
korea101.summary: Korean convenience stores are far more than snack shops.
korea101.hook: When confused, start from the nearest convenience store.
korea101.friend_note: You can solve meals, chargers, transit top-up, and quick logistics in one stop.
korea101.comic_scene: A traveler enters for water and exits with a hot meal, umbrella, and recharged transit card.
korea101.core_idea: 24/7 convenience stores are practical infrastructure in urban Korea.
korea101.fun_fact: Microwave + instant noodle station culture is common in many branches.
korea101.real_life_tip: Look for machine corners: ticketing, delivery services, and print options vary by branch.
korea101.line_to_use: Can I top up my transit card here?

korea101.title: Seasons, Rain, and Dust
korea101.summary: Korean weather can swing hard, so daily adaptation matters.
korea101.hook: Same city, totally different vibe by season.
korea101.friend_note: Layering and checking fine-dust apps matter more than many first-timers expect.
korea101.comic_scene: Sunny morning selfie, surprise rain at lunch, and chilly night wind after dinner.
korea101.core_idea: Plan with weather buffers, not rigid outfit assumptions.
korea101.fun_fact: Monsoon season can turn short walks into full reroutes within one hour.
korea101.real_life_tip: Carry a compact umbrella and light outerwear from spring to autumn.

korea101.title: Basic Korean Speech Mode
korea101.summary: You do not need fluency, but tone level changes social comfort.
korea101.friend_note: Start polite, then mirror the other person’s tone if they soften first.
korea101.comic_scene: A beginner uses one polite phrase and receives unexpectedly warm help.
korea101.core_idea: Respect markers in speech are a social signal in everyday interactions.
korea101.fun_fact: Korean has multiple speech levels, and locals switch levels by context fast.
korea101.real_life_tip: Use short polite phrases: hello, thank you, excuse me, please.
korea101.line_to_use: Excuse me, can you help me?

korea101.title: Social & Night Culture
korea101.summary: Dinner, drinks, and second rounds are part of social rhythm.
korea101.hook: The night often continues longer than visitors expect.
korea101.friend_note: You can enjoy the vibe without matching every round of alcohol.
korea101.comic_scene: Someone thinks the night is over after dinner, then friends say, “Round 2 starts now.”
korea101.core_idea: Group bonding often extends across multiple venues in one evening.
korea101.fun_fact: Second round culture (2-cha) is common in both friend groups and work circles.
korea101.real_life_tip: Set your own pace early and suggest non-alcohol options confidently.
korea101.line_to_use: I am good with one drink, thank you.

korea101.title: Work & School Vibe
korea101.summary: Group chats, punctuality, and context reading are key.
korea101.hook: Fast replies can feel like teamwork, not pressure.
korea101.friend_note: If you are late, message early with one clear sentence.
korea101.comic_scene: A newcomer misses a group chat update and arrives at the wrong cafe.
korea101.core_idea: Digital coordination is central to Korean work and student routines.
korea101.fun_fact: Many plans are finalized in chat right before the event time.
korea101.real_life_tip: Check group chat before leaving and again on arrival.
korea101.line_to_use: I might be 10 minutes late. Sorry.

korea101.title: Health, Pharmacy, and Emergency
korea101.summary: Basic medical navigation is easier when prepared in advance.
korea101.hook: A small prep list prevents big panic moments.
korea101.friend_note: Save your hotel address in Korean and one emergency contact early.
korea101.comic_scene: Late-night cold symptoms hit, and the nearest pharmacy search becomes a mini mission.
korea101.core_idea: Know where to go: pharmacy for mild issues, clinic/hospital for escalation.
korea101.fun_fact: Many neighborhoods have multiple pharmacies clustered near stations or hospitals.
korea101.real_life_tip: Keep your passport copy and insurance details accessible on phone.
korea101.line_to_use: I need medicine for a cold.
